THE CONSERVANCY CAPITALIZES CERTAIN COSTS INCURRED DURING THE TIME THE LAND IS BEING ACQUIRED AND PROTECTION ACTIVITIES ARE UNDERWAY. THE COSTS INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT, LAND IMPROVEMENTS, LEGAL FEES, AND MISCELLANEOUS OTHER ITEMS. GRANTS RECEIVED AS REIMBURSEMENT FOR LAND COSTS ON PROJECTS WHERE THE CONSERVANCY DOES NOT INTEND TO HOLD THE LAND FOR LONG-TERM PURPOSES REDUCE THE COST OF THE LAND. EASEMENTS ACQUIRED THROUGH DONATION AND EASEMENTS ESTABLISHED BY RESERVATION OF RIGHTS ARE NOT RECORDED IN THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. ADDITIONALLY, THE CONSERVANCY OBTAINS EASEMENTS THROUGH PURCHASES DIRECTLY FROM OWNERS. PURCHASED EASEMENTS ARE RECORDED AT COST AND REDUCED TO A CARRYING VALUE OF $1 BY THE AMOUNT OF ANY RESTRICTED GRANTS RECEIVED SPECIFICALLY FOR THE EASEMENT PURCHASES AND BY EXPENSING THE AMOUNT OF THE EASEMENT PURCHASE FUNDED BY UNRESTRICTED REVENUE. AS DISCUSSED ABOVE, GRANTS RECEIVED AS REIMBURSEMENT FOR LAND COSTS ON LAND CONSERVATION PROJECTS WHERE THE CONSERVANCY DOES NOT INTEND TO HOLD THE LAND FOR THE LONG-TERM REDUCE THE COST BASIS OF THE LAND. FALLINGWATER WAS DESIGNED IN 1935 BY FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AS A WEEKEND HOUSE FOR THE EDGAR J. KAUFMANN FAMILY OF PITTSBURGH. CONSTRUCTED BETWEEN 1936 AND 1939, IT COMBINED INNOVATIVE ENGINEERING AND DESIGN WITH MODERN MATERIALS IN A WAY THAT HELPED INSTILL MODERNISM AS A POWERFUL MOVEMENT IN AMERICA. DRAMATICALLY CANTILEVERED OVER THE WATERFALL OF BEAR RUN, THE HOUSE WAS CONSTRUCTED OF REINFORCED CONCRETE AND NATIVE SANDSTONE QUARRIED ON THE SITE. IT IS COMPRISED OF A SERIES OF REINFORCED CONCRETE TRAYS STACKED ONE UPON THE OTHER AND SEPARATED BY STONE PIERS. THE FIRST FLOOR CONSISTS OF THE LIVING, DINING AND KITCHEN AREAS; THE SECOND AND THIRD LEVELS HAVE A TOTAL OF FOUR BEDROOMS EACH WITH A BATH AND TERRACE. CLIMBING THE HILL BEHIND THE HOUSE IS THE GUEST HOUSE AND SERVANTS QUARTERS. FALLINGWATER'S ART COLLECTION IS COMPRISED OF MORE THAN 950 WORKS OF FINE AND DECORATIVE ART INCLUDING PRINTS, PAINTINGS, SCULPTURE, FURNITURE, CERAMICS, ART GLASS, AND MISCELLANEOUS HOUSEHOLD OBJECTS. OF PARTICULAR SIGNIFICANCE IN THE COLLECTION ARE THE 169 PIECES OF ORIGINAL WALNUT FURNITURE, CUSTOM DESIGNED BY FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT FOR FALLINGWATER. THESE PIECES REPRESENT ONE OF THE MOST COMPLETE ENSEMBLES OF WRIGHT DESIGNED, SITE-SPECIFIC FURNITURE. THE REMAINING ARTIFACTS ON DISPLAY REPRESENT AN ECLECTIC RANGE OF OBJECTS COLLECTED BY THE KAUFMANN FAMILY. THEY UNDERLINE THE FAMILY'S BELIEF IN THE POWER OF GOOD DESIGN TO ENRICH THE QUALITY OF MODERN LIFE, A BELIEF SHARED BY FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT. IN ADDITION TO WORKS OF ART, THERE ARE 1,340 FAMILY BOOKS, INCLUDING AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF ARCHITECTURAL BOOKS. THE FALLINGWATER ARCHIVES CONTAIN: 396 PHOTOGRAPHS (1880-1996) OF THE BEAR RUN REGION, FALLINGWATER AND SURROUNDING PROPERTY, CONSTRUCTION OF THE HOUSE, AND MEMBERS OF THE EDGAR J. KAUFMANN FAMILY; 875 PHOTOGRAPHS OF WESTERN PA BY REGIONAL PHOTOGRAPHER LUKE SWANK; 1,100 DOCUMENTS (1934-1989) RELATING TO THE KAUFMANN FAMILY'S OWNERSHIP AND ASSOCIATION WITH FALLINGWATER; 16 MAPS OF THE SURROUNDING AREA, 3 ORIGINAL PENCIL DRAWINGS BY VICTOR HAMMER; 150 COPIES OF DRAWINGS PRODUCED BY WRIGHT FOR THE KAUFMANNS (THE ORIGINALS WERE PLACED AT COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY'S AVERY LIBRARY BY EDGAR KAUFMANN, JR. PRIOR TO HIS GIFT OF FALLINGWATER TO THE WPC); 108 PUBLICATIONS RELATED TO THE HOUSE AND FAMILY; 60 MINUTES OF BLACK AND WHITE FILM FOOTAGE THAT INCLUDES HOME MOVIES OF THE FAMILY, THE BEAR RUN PROPERTY PRIOR TO THE CONSTRUCTION OF FALLINGWATER, AND FILMS OF THE CONSTRUCTION ITSELF; 5 VIDEO TAPES AND 25 ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS OF FORMER KAUFMANN EMPLOYEES AND FRIENDS, AND APPROXIMATELY 1,000 PIECES OF ORIGINAL KAUFMANN CORRESPONDENCE. A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK SINCE 1976, FALLINGWATER IS AN INTERNATIONAL TREASURE. IN 2000, THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA NAMED FALLINGWATER A COMMONWEALTH TREASURE, AND A SURVEY OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF ARCHITECTS' MEMBERS VOTED FALLINGWATER THE BUILDING OF THE CENTURY, BY A 3-TO-1 MARGIN. IN 2015, FALLINGWATER WAS PUT FORTH BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE FOR CONSIDERATION AS A UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE WITH NINE OTHER WRIGHT BUILDINGS. IT IS THE ONLY MAJOR WRIGHT-DESIGNED BUILDING TO HAVE COME INTO THE PUBLIC DOMAIN INTACT, COMPLETE WITH THE BUILDING, LANDSCAPE, ORIGINAL WRIGHT-DESIGNED FURNISHINGS, AND FAMILY'S ART COLLECTION. FALLINGWATER AND ITS COLLECTIONS ARE AN INVALUABLE PUBLIC RESOURCE. WITH CLOSE TO 167,000 VISITORS ANNUALLY, THE MUSEUM SERVES AS AN EDUCATIONAL AND CULTURAL INSTITUTION FOR THE GLOBAL COMMUNITY.

The Fund acted as a fiscal agent for Chicago Public Schools (CPS) in connection with the CPS principal bonus plan that began in 2012. This agreement provided that The Fund would accept payment of pledges from various donors secured by CPS, and would process annual bonus payments to school principals, as directed by CPS. During 2015, donations in the amount of $276,666 were collected from donors and recorded to the statements of financial position as a liability, and $435,000 was disbursed for principal bonus payments. After the bonus payments to principals were made in 2015, CPS and the donors agreed to terminate this agreement, and The Fund refunded the remaining $270,666 of unspent funds to the donors. Additionally, during 2014, The Fund agreed to serve as fiscal agent on behalf of Crown Family Philanthropies (Crown) with respect to the CPS Principal Fellowship Program in partnership with Northwestern University. The second of two $200,000 payments was received in 2015. In 2015, $300,000 was disbursed under the direction of Crown, leaving a balance of $100,000 to be disbursed over the remaining term of the agreement, which ends in October 2016.

The accounting standard on accounting for uncertainty in income taxes addressed the determination of whether tax benefits claimed on a tax return should be recorded in the financial statements. Under this guidance, The Fund may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position. Examples of tax positions include the tax-exempt status of The Fund and the various positions related to the potential sources of unrelated business taxable income (UBTI). The tax benefits recognized in the financial statement from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50 percent likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement. The Fund does not believe that there are any unrecognized tax benefits or tax liabilities that should be recorded for the reporting periods presented in these financial statements. The Fund is generally no longer subject to examination by the Internal Revenue Service for years before 2012.
